name: Revenue Model Spreadsheet
description: Build a structured revenue model covering all three brainstormed product ideas (Audio Ad Stripper, Smart PDF Redactor, Podcast Show Notes Generator) with API costs, pricing tiers, break-even analysis, and 30/60/90 day revenue projections.

tasks.title: Scoped requirements for revenue model analysis
subtasks: Reviewed Custom Meeting #3 transcript to identify all three product ideas and associated cost/pricing data from the brainstorm
Reviewed meeting decisions: per-use pricing consensus, build effort estimates, success thresholds
Cross-referenced with monetization strategy doc and SherlockPDF tech approach for infrastructure context
Defined deliverable structure: cost structure, pricing tiers, unit economics, 30/60/90 projections, comparison table
Set conservative adoption assumptions appropriate for a small indie team with no marketing budget
Identified reference docs Yuki should read before starting
Determined lean pipeline: Thomas scoping only, Yuki executes, no other agents needed
decisions: Analytical project only — no software build, no architecture, no design, no QA pipeline needed
Markdown with tables as output format — simple, readable, no tooling overhead
Yuki is sole executor — no downstream agents unless she identifies specific gaps
Conservative adoption assumptions: 5-15 paying users at 30 days, not optimistic projections

tasks.title: Produce revenue model analysis document
subtasks: Read and cross-referenced 6 source documents: requirements doc, Meeting #3 transcript, monetization strategy, payments research, SherlockPDF tech approach, agent definition
Researched current Gemini 2.5 Flash API pricing from Google's published rates (Feb 2026): $0.30/1M text input, $1.00/1M audio input, $2.50/1M output
Built cost structure for Audio Ad Stripper: $0.25 avg API cost/file, $0.77 total cost/file at $3.99 price point
Built cost structure for Smart PDF Redactor: $0.02 avg API cost/file, $0.44 total cost/file at $2.99 price point
Built cost structure for Podcast Show Notes Generator: $0.45 avg API cost/file, $0.90 total cost/file at $2.49 price point
Defined 3 pricing tiers per product (per-file, small bundle, large bundle) aligned with meeting consensus on per-use pricing
Calculated unit economics: gross margins ranging from 64% (Show Notes per-episode) to 93% (Redactor bundles)
Calculated break-even volumes: Redactor 2 files/month, Ad Stripper 4 files/month, Show Notes 6 files/month
Built 30/60/90 day projections for all three products with low/mid/high scenarios using Thomas's conservative adoption assumptions
Created comparison table ranking all three products across 13 dimensions including revenue, margins, build effort, infrastructure advantage, and technical risk
Documented all 12 assumptions explicitly with basis and risk-if-wrong for each

Produced build-order ranking: Redactor first (highest profit, best margins, existing infrastructure), Ad Stripper second (viral potential, strong margins), Show Notes third (fastest build but lowest margins)
decisions: Corrected Marco's 2-3 cent API estimate upward: at published Gemini 2.5 Flash audio rates ($1.00/1M tokens), a 30-min file costs ~$0.49, not 2-3 cents. Used $0.25 blended average accounting for shorter files and batch mode.
Used blended average API costs rather than worst-case to reflect realistic usage mix of file lengths and potential batch mode savings
Weighted revenue per user by estimated tier mix rather than assuming all users buy at the cheapest tier
Gave PDF Redactor slightly higher 30-day user estimates (8 low vs 5) to reflect SherlockPDF's existing distribution channel as a zero-cost acquisition advantage
Ranked Redactor first despite longest build time because effective time-to-revenue is shortest when infrastructure and distribution are factored in
